text: During the month of November we will be accepting in date, nonperishable food items to pay for fines*. All donations will be given to the Anaconda Food Bank. This is a great way to pay off your late fees and help the community at the same time! Call 563-6932 or stop in for more information. *Food for fines does not apply to fees for damaged, lost or stolen items.

Bigger. Stronger. Faster. We have launched our new and improved catalog, and we¡¯re sure you will love it. This catalog has features you have been requesting like sorting by format, texting of records you might want to save or share with others, list creation and storage, and easier placement of holds and reserves. An optional RSS feed will deliver lists of new titles to you via email or text and a customized search option can notify you of books by specific authors or subjects. Stop by the Library and ask any librarian for a quick demo.

Just to clarify, we are NOT providing all the supplies on the school supply lists.

So here's something you don't hear every day... One of our staff members had a huge bruise on her forearm. When we asked her what happened, her answer was something that the vast majority of us will never get to hear or say. "I was bitten by a zebra!" It turns out that it was true! She was at a petting zoo, and a baby zebra came up to her and clamped his little jaws right onto her arm while she was petting another animal. Could it be that she might end up with a Bad Case of Stripes, like the book by David Shannon??? Stay tuned to this page, and we'll let you know if any unusual patterns start developing! ??

Thank you so much London, your generosity is greatly appreciated!

Perseid Meteor Shower UPDATE: Taking local weather into account, we've pushed the Randall Oaks Library outside stargazing program up to Tonight at 3:00am to take advantage of the clear skies. This could be your only shot to experience what they're forecasting to be a brilliant star show! We'll have music, astronomy books for checkout, and more. For maximum comfort bring your blankets, chairs, bug spray, and maybe a jacket. We'll be set up on the soccer field/grassy area outside the Randall Oaks Library.

On Thursday, August 20th the Sonora Main Library is offering an Active Art program for children of all ages from 3:30 to 5:00 PM in the Community Meeting Room. Boys and girls will create art and explore new textures by spinning, shaking, rolling, and playing with paints. Some of the activities include using salad spinners, magnets, marbles, Lego wheels, yarn, and other found objects. This event will be messy but we will have over-sized tee shirts for children to wear over their clothes. The library is located at 480 Greenley Road in Sonora. The Tuolumne County Library will hold Family Movie Matinee on August 15 from 2 to 4 p.m. This event is free to the public. This month¡¯s family-friendly movie will be ¡°Open Season.¡± The film features Boog, a domesticated 900-pound grizzly bear, who finds himself stranded in the woods just days before the onset of hunting season. He is forced to rely on a fast-talking mule deer, named Elliot, and gather help from a variety of furry forest animals to stand up to dangerous hunters. Featuring loveable characters voiced by stars like Martin Lawrence and Ashton Kutcher, the movie is rated PG and is 83 minutes long. The film will be shown in the community meeting room at the Sonora Main Library at 480 Greenly Road in Sonora. Local families and kids are welcome to come for the movie, enjoy some popcorn and socialize.

Come visit Fonzi today from 3:30 to 4:30 at Sonora Main Library. The certified International Therapy Dog Fonzi will be visiting Sonora Main Library's Children Room today. Children may select a book to read to him or just come and visit.

TEEN ADVISORY BOARD AWARDS LAST NIGHT Our TAB program has got to be one of the best around, and last night the top TAB volunteers were honored at the Library Board Meeting (told you you should have come). She is hardworking, creative, artistic and dedicated to her community. (Graduated, Attending Cal State LA) David Herrera is a big supporter and promoter of the Library teen programs, and dedicated his time to running No Shush Wednesday for his peers. He is a great role model for younger TAB members and brings fresh ideas to every meeting. (Senior, Monrovia High School)

This Just in: Solfia Talvik will be joining Moulton's Reading in The Garden on Wednesday. She will be playing before noon as guests filter in and again in the afternoon. Tickets are still available for $10 here at the library. They will be $12 at the door. Sofia Talvik is the next rising star from Sweden. She has emerged like a lady of the forest, bringing a new interesting side to folk music. She¡¯s playing a unique blend of folk-pop (someone said Neo-Folk). This American genre filtered through her Swedish heritage, becomes something totally unique, a blend that has attracted attention from American reviewers, blogs and music lovers, allowing her tour the US several times. In 2008, she became the first Swedish female singer to play the Lollapalooza festival in Chicago. http://sofiatalvik.com

Our Library Management System vendor has informed us the issue has not been resolved. Services should be restored.

Our Library Management System vendor, Book Systems, advised this morning they are experiencing a network issue that is impacting the service of our LMS. Currently, we are not able to access this system. As this system validates Camellia Net users and patron access to our public access computers, patrons may experience difficulties in attempting to use these services. This also impacts our ability to access patron accounts if a patron calls requesting we renew items for them. We regret any inconvenience this may cause our patrons. Our vendor is working on the issue as quickly as possible.

The Lawrence County Public Library would like to congratulate the winners of this year's Summer Reading Program. First place winner, Breanna Luna; Second place, Payton Foster-McLean; and third place, Joshua Jetton. We would also like to recognize that every participant are winners in our book! After all, "Every Hero Has a Story!" Prizes were made possible through a grant from the United Way of Lawrence County received by the Friends of the Lawrence County Public Library.
Hopefully we can have all the photos from yesterday's Summer Reading Program ready to post tomorrow, but until we do, here is the group shot with the Moulton Fire Department.

The Lawrence County Public Library had a successful Summer Reading program! We had a total of 343 people attend the program. Our attendance averaged 49 children and 37 adults per week. That is an amazing 32% increase over the previous year! We would like to thank our sponsors: the Friends of the Lawrence County Public Library, United Way of Lawrence County, and Taco Bell. We would also like to thank the Moulton Lions Club for allowing us to use their facility. Our programs were provided by Yarbrough's Education Reptiles and the McWane Science Center. Special thanks to our local heroes, the Lawrence County Sheriff's Department and the Moulton Fire Department for the programs they provided as well! The theme was very fitting this year, "Every Hero Has a Story!"
Last week's Summer Reading Program with the McWane Science Center.

The Lawrence County Public Library will have a Children¡¯s Storytime planning session on Thursday, July 30th at 1:30 p.m for the 2015-2016 school year. Any individuals who are interested in volunteering for Storytime are invited to attend. Library Storytimes play an important role in early childhood literacy. According to the Program for Early Parent Support, ¡°children benefit from hearing another adult read to them, from watching other children get engaged in a story, and from being exposed to a wide variety of authors and writing styles. Your child will also learn some essential school readiness skills, like how to sit still for an extended period of time, how to pay attention to an adult other than his parents, how to take turns, and how to be (reasonably) quiet in a public place.¡± The Children Storytime occurs weekly during the school year. The program is held on Thursdays from 10 a.m.-11 a.m., and is open to children from infancy to five years-old. Children must be accompanied by an adult.
Photos from this week's Summer Reading Program. https://picasaweb.google.com/¡­/SummerReadingProgram2015Week¡­

We had 61 children in attendance at yesterday's first Summer Reading Program event of the year. That is almost double the children's attendance of 38 for last year's first event. Thanks to Ginger Grantham from the The The Moulton Advertiser coming out to photograph the event! The Summer Reading Program is made possible through donations from the United Way of Lawrence County, Alabama and Friends of the Lawrence County Public Library.

Cookbook Club on Friday, September 25th @ 11:00 a.m. "Jerusalem: A Cookbook" by Yotam Ottolenghi and Sami Tamimi. Wanting to try something new, something you enjoy doing? Try DKPL's Cook Book Club! The Gale Library, Newton is joining the NH 1000 Books Before Kindergarten initiative. The single most important thing you can do to prepare your children to read is to read to them every day. Research proves that children need to hear 1000 books before they begin to learn to read independently. Reading to children will increase their vocabulary and their listening and narrative skills. Reading with children will also help to instill in them self-awareness, confidence and an understanding of their place in the world. It¡¯s easy to read 1000 books: One book a day for three years=1000 Three books a day for one year=1000 Ten books a week for two years=1000 Everything counts! Every book you read counts every time you read it! Books your child hears in Storytime count. Books that others read to your child count. It all counts! Story Time Report ¨C Today we listened to folktales from Mexico. In ¡°Borreguita and the Coyote¡±, the little lamb outsmarted the coyote three times and he never bothered her again! A tiny ant was the hero in ¡°The Goat and the Chile Peppers¡±. She alone, was able to get that naughty goat out of the garden when so many others who were more powerful failed in the task. We also sang songs, played rhythm instruments, moved our bodies, played with puzzles and other educational toys, looked at picture books and made delicious looking paper tacos to take home. I hope to see you next week for some Halloween stories and activities. Mrs. Halleck

Story Time Report: Yesterday we enjoyed learning about one of the most endangered mammals on the earth: the rhinoceros. We noticed important physical features and loved seeing baby rhinos in the photographs. In the art area, we hid a paper rhino under layers of colorful paint and then when it was flipped to the side like a page in a book, it showed the rhino shape once again, this time revealing its highly textured skin. Let us hope that real rhinos will be seen in the wild on our earth forever. We listened to a few stories with rhino characters but few authors use rhinos as central characters. Our nonfiction examples were a bit wordy for the preschool group but could definitely be enjoyed at home during story time with a parent. There is much to learn about these ancient animals. Next Friday at 10 AM we will take one last trip to Africa to see giraffes. I hope to see you there! ¨C Mrs. Halleck

Neil Gaiman: "We have an obligation to support libraries. To use libraries, to encourage others to use libraries, to protest the closure of libraries. If you do not value libraries then you do not value information or culture or wisdom. You are silencing the voices of the past and you are damaging the future. We have an obligation to read aloud to our children. To read them things they enjoy. To read to them stories we are already tired of. To do the voices, to make it interesting, and not to stop reading to them just because they learn to read to themselves. Use reading-aloud time as bonding time, as time when no phones are being checked, when the distractions of the world are put aside. We have an obligation to use the language. To push ourselves: to find out what words mean and how to deploy them, to communicate clearly, to say what we mean. We must not to attempt to freeze language, or to pretend it is a dead thing that must be revered, but we should use it as a living thing, that flows, that borrows words, that allows meanings and pronunciations to change with time." http://www.theguardian.com/¡­/neil-gaiman-future-libraries-r¡­

Every Hero Has a Story - Summer Reading Program Our Summer Reading Program was a great success. Thank you to all of our sponsors and volunteers! With out you we wouldn't be able to put this program on. Also a big thanks to all the parents who get their kids, and some even the neighbors kids, to the park to participate. "Over 30 years of studies consistently show that students who do not continue reading over the summer lose as much as 3 to 4 months of academic progress. This is especially true for low-income children. While children in higher-income families have access to books and participate in activities that support continued learning, children in low-income families have few books in the home and have restricted access to them. By the end of the sixth grade much of the achievement gap between high-income and low-income children can be attributed to loss of learning over the summer months. Some studies estimate that this gap can be as wide as three years." From ¡°Summer Reading: Closing the Rich/Poor Achievement Gap,¡± by Richard L. Allington and Anne McGill-Franzen. Teachers College Press, Columbia University, NY, and the International Reading Association. 2013. Because of this research, we will continue to encourage reading this summer by keeping our book buck store open throughout August. Book bucks are earned by reading, for every hour a child reads, or is read to, they earn one book buck. Book bucks are then redeemed in the book buck store located in the library.

The perfect Halloween! I sit in the library and listen to conversations the kids have with each other. The past few weeks most discussions have settled on "what are you going to be for Halloween"? The internet has been searched for costume ideas and plans have been made. I remember being that kid. Halloween was by far one of the most important days of the year. The anticipation of dressing up and roaming the streets for free candy consumed most of October. And the traditions have been passed along to the next generations. Yet I wonder as I listen to conversations, WHY? is Halloween changing for so many adults. I hear people laugh and say we sit in the house with our lights off or we leave for the night. Halloween has been pushed aside for some years as other events have taken the spotlight. However, this year is one of the few ( Perfect Halloweens) as it falls on a Saturday night. The trick or treaters have the night the weather is perfect and they have made their plans. We as the older generation have the ability to keep our Halloween for the next generations. It is as simple as turning on that porch light and waiting for the doorbell to ring. Enjoy it! These kids have put a lot of thought into this night.

A child had written a note, 'Take all you want. God is watching the apples.

photos It is generally recognized that fireworks originated in China during the Sung dynasty (960-1279). A cook in ancient China discovered that a mixture of sulphur, saltpetre, and charcoal was highly flammable and would explode if confined in a small space. This discovery was first used for entertainment. The technique was soon adapted to weaponry and used to shoot rocket-powered arrows. In the 7th century the knowledge spread west via Arabia, reaching Europe in the 13th century where pyrotechnics developed with the invention of the gun in the 14th century. It was not until the 19th century that fireworks became as vividly colourful as we know them today. Brilliant colours are achieved by combining potassium chlorate and various metallic salts. These salts produce a variety of colours: strontium burns red; copper makes blue; barium glows green; and sodium produces yellow. Magnesium, aluminium and titanium give off white sparkles or a flash. Every firework show is a fantastic display of physics. The pyrotechnist has to take into account the relationships between vectors, velocities, projectiles and their trajectories together with the explosion forces behind burst patterns.

Laderrica Lucas enjoys one of the library's two newest additions to its children's area. These Early Literacy Stations? (ELS), are designed specifically for our youngest library users ages 2-8, and features over 4,000 localized learning activities. The fun, interactive and engaging content spans all seven curricular areas: math, science & nature, social studies & geography, reading, art & music, writing & computer skills, and reference. We have two of these stations that can both accommodate two users at a time and are both bilingual (English and Spanish).

HELP WANTED! The Sewickley Township Public Library is seeking an energetic, outgoing person for the position of Library Assistant. Computer proficiency, customer service skills, and the ability to multi-task are a must. Primary responsibilities will be to provide front desk customer assistance including checkouts, payments, registration, readers advisory, help with computers, and eBook downloads. State and FBI clearances required upon hire. One evening per week and 2 Saturdays per month. Additional hours are possible, as needed. Salary is $7.25/hour. Please send letter and resume by August 31st to Mandy at sewtwp@nb.net or 201 Highland Avenue, Herminie, PA 15637.

Do You Know Texas Has 14 National Parks? Everything is big in Texas, so why wouldn¡¯t there be exceptional national parks? But, can you name them? LBJ National Historical Park Superintendent Russ Witlock will fill us in on all the national treasures in our great state Tuesday September 22, at 6:00 pm at the Johnson City Library. The National Parks system evolved over the course of more than 150 years, with a sometimes conflicting two part-mission: to make the parks accessible to all and to preserve them for future generations. The Johnson City Librarys Discovery Academy is very proud to have been awarded a grant from the Texas State Library and Archives Commission (TCLAC). Discovery, a collaboration with JCISD, is an after school enrichment program in science and math with hands-on experiments and activities. Discoverys mission is to reinforce what children learn in the classroom and foster a life-long love of learning. This session starts with a LEGO challenge. The theme this year is Waste Wise- learning to look at trash in a whole new way. The grant allows the library to offer free registration to all students in the 3rd-5th grades. The first day of Discovery is Sept. 15, and registration forms are available at the library. Heres an article by Mark Smith, the Director of TSLAC that talks about some of the other wonderful library programs across the state that were also funded. The projects funded by these grants are an amazing panorama of innovation, best practice, and forward direction in library service. The projects include initiatives that will reinforce the new model of libraries as learning centers such as 3-D Labs @ Your Library, a CTLS project to put 3-D printers at the core of a network of librarians sharing expertise for the benefit of patrons; or the Johnson City Public Library¡¯s Discovery Academy that will provide STEM learning opportunities for third to fifth-grade students. Many of the projects funded in this round will explore exciting new models of sustainability for libr

Join us on Monday evening, August 3 at 6 pm for another fun (and free) family movie night. The film features four super-spy penguins from Madagascar who are on a mission to save the planet! Bring your own snacks if you wish (we'll have popcorn) and a pillow, blanket, or yoga mat for the kids.

Join us on Saturday, July 25th at noon for the Chewonki Foundation's ¡°Hero Adaptations¡±. This fun and free event ¨C featuring live animals - is part of the library's ¡°Superheroes¡± vacation reading program. Many of our favorite superheroes are inspired by animals living in our own backyards. Have you ever wondered if those superpowers and abilities could actually exist in the natural world? The program will demonstrate the connections between superpowers and the adaptations of their animal counterparts. The fun involves a close-up look at three fascinating animals and an opportunity for participants to enter into a statewide contest to create their own owl-inspired superhero.

The kids really did ask some great questions! I think we should invite Officer Mike to come back again sometime. Many thanks to Officer Mike Parshall for tonight's visit - and to him and all the officers of the Monmouth PD for keeping our community safe.

On Tuesday night, July 21st at 6 pm, the library will have another of its popular movie nights. The film features a young Peruvian bear who travels to London in search of a home. Lost and alone at Paddington Station, he finally meets the kindly Brown family and is offered a temporary haven. The film will be shown on the air-conditioned lower level. Bring your own snacks (we'll have popcorn) and a pillow, blanket, or yoga mat.

Super-creative: bring your kids to the library's lower level on Monday night between 6-8 p.m. for an evening of ¡°DIY¡± book binding. Learn how to make unique notepads, coloring books, journals, drawing pads, and more using old books, greeting cards, duct tape, and other materials. Bring a favorite photo, drawing, card, or calendar page and give it a new life! We have the means to do spiral binding, and will teach some simple hand-binding techniques as well.

New adult fiction includes ¡°Day Four¡± by Sarah Lotz, ¡°Palace of Treason¡± by Jason Matthews, and ¡°Scents and Sensibility¡±, the latest in the popular ¡°Chet & Bernie¡± series by Spencer Quinn. New nonfiction includes ¡°The Power of Meow¡± by David Michie. We have lots of new books for younger readers also, including picture books, easy readers, beginning chapter books, and more. New graphic novels include ¡°Rocket Raccoon¡± and ¡°Lumberjanes¡±.

Summer reading has come to a close! We had a great time as we celebrated "Every Hero Has A Story"! The Toledo Zoo program was very interesting as we learned about heroes in the animal kingdom and the powers that animals have! We have done the prize drawings for each of the reading groups and the winners are: Children's program T-shirts - Olivia Strieter-Byron and Jonathan Petraru ; Teen program Kindle Fire - Savannah Mott ; Adult program Kindle Fire - Sarah Koski. Thanks to all who made this summer so much fun!

Thursday, August 20, 2015, is going to be an exciting day at the Clinton Township Public Library! We will have representatives from the Toledo Zoo Educational Department here to present a special program about animals! Call to local Artists- The capital campaign for the Poultney Public Library is underway! We have planned an arts fundraiser for this summer. This fundraiser will include live music, art demonstrations, an art and rare book silent auction, and a dessert sale. We are hoping you will contribute a piece of art for our Art and Rare Book Silent Auction to be held on August 21, 2015 from 6-8pm. The library has enjoyed many collaborative events with the local art community, and we are looking forward to more joint programs and displays once the library expands! Any questions please stop by the library or give us a call at 802-287-5556.

This summer from June first to September first, ninety-nine Vermont public and academic libraries will be handing out passports and encouraging patrons to visit some of Vermont's unique, beautiful and creative libraries. You can pick up your passport at the Poultney Public Library! Local libraries will offer passport stamps. The adult, young adult, and child from Poultney Public Library that visit the most libraries will receive a gift certificate for a free pound of fudge at The Original Vermont Store. Three patrons statewide (adult, young adult, child) will receive Vermont Library Ambassador awards for visiting the most libraries and a copy of the classic book on Vermont's libraries Where the Books Are a book about the history and architecture of Vermont's public libraries by Pat Belding.

Thank you to all of our trustees, staff, volunteers, and shoppers for a fantastic Book Sale! We made $1,853.50 at our sale on Friday, July 3. We had huge amounts of donated books, and have lots left over. We have two carts of individually priced books that we will continue to sell throughout the summer. We have lots of leftover kids and teen books that we will be selling for $1/bag for the next week or two. There are also three boxes of movies, computer games, and audio books still left. I have put those outside for FREE so come grab them while they last! The rest of our leftovers will be sent to Better World Books. They will sell them for us online. We will get a portion of the proceeds from those sales, and a portion will also go towards supporting literacy charities. Thanks again for a wonderful day! (Here is a picture of Denise and Olivia putting together all the boxes we use to ship out books to Better World Books.)

SUMMER READING PROGRAM 2015 "Every Hero Has a Story" this summer at the Bartlett Public Library. Grab your cape and favorite books and join us for the BPL's summer reading program. Events will be held weekly to celebrate our heroes as well as reading! Activities will be hero- themed and designed to promote literacy. Defeat the "summer slide" by reading and earn prizes by playing our Summer Reading BINGO. Summer Reading BINGO logs will be available throughout the duration of the program. No registration is required. Tuesdays, July 7th- August 4th 9:30 Story time program for children ages 0-5 and their caregivers 10:00 School-aged program for students in grades K-6 August 4th 10:00 am Don't Miss out on out on our final celebration brought to us by the Children's Museum of New Hampshire: High Flying Heroes! "How does flight work? Who are the pioneering high-flying heroes in the history of aviation? Why does a kite fly through the air? These questions and more will be answered in this summer's library outreach program! A museum educator will lead children in a one-hour hands-on workshop filled with exciting science concepts and demonstrations. Watch as a real Bernoulli blower makes objects hover in the air ... build and test paper flying contraptions ... and make a lunch sack kite to take home and fly!" -taken from childrens-museum.org

Check out our Oral History Workshop storyteller and join us on Saturday from 2-4 for a great workshop learning how to share our heritage. This interactive program is ideal for conferences, church groups, clubs, libraries, and retirees. Many techniques are given for gathering and sharing family stories that reveal Aha! moments about who we are and what our family gifts and curses are. Using family photos, artifacts, and songs to get the juices flowing, many workshop participants experience epiphanies and connect with their families and communities in a new and enriched way.

Join us this Saturday, September 19, 2015 from 11:30 am - 12:15 pm in the Beaverton City Library Auditorium for Vellamo, a Finnish Folk Concert. Vellamo is the performing and songwriting team of Pia Leinonen and Joni Tiala. Their music is characterized by haunting melodies, Pia's ethereal lead vocals and Joni's virtuosic guitar stylings. They write instantly memorable songs in English as well as their native Finnish, and also perform traditional ballads from the Finnish, Celtic and Scandinavian folk traditions. This event is free and open to the public.

Saturday, October 24 at 12:30: Do you love to color? Do you love to paint? Local artists Nancy and Amy Lucas from the 321 Art Studio will guide artists through the step-by-step process to create a Minnesota autumn landscape with Neocolor crayons and then transform the drawing into a water color style painting with a bit of water. This family program is fun for all ages. Preschool age children will need the help of a parent or grandparent while those older will enjoy the opportunity to learn basic drawing techniques and color blending. Then use what you have learned to create your own masterpiece

Reminder: Wednesday, October 14 at 1:30 pm: Arna Rennan¡¯s songs span from ballads of the middle ages, stev, broadsides, hymns and dance tunes. She also plays the langeleik (relative of the dolcimer), seljefloeyte (overtone flute) and piano accordion. Her Music of the Immigrant program is a program for adult audiences that shares songs about immigration, longing for their homeland, as well as vaudeville comedy tunes with mixed language and music.

There has been a great deal of publicity regarding the phenomenon known as "Summer Slide." This occurs when children who are out of school for the summer and frequently away from reading and learning experiences, lose some of their reading and language abilities which were gained during the previous school year. There has been a movement to supplement language experiences during the summer by providing more access to books and reading. In that spirit, the Monson Public Library is offering a free (yes, free) book to each child when they come in for a visit as long as supplies last. While all children are able to borrow a library book, owning their own book is very special. Most of the books are picture books, but there are a few books for older readers as well. This is your invitation to visit the library with your young person and pick out a book--ours or yours to keep.

It is this day a year ago that the Friends of the Harriette Person Memorial Library began their journey anew. It's hard to believe that a year has passed and FHPML is commemorating their first year. FHPML has done great things for the Library and has helped to improve the Library's presence in the community. If you would like to be a part of their growing history, please feel free to contact any member of the Friends Group, come by the Library and speak with the Librarian or attend a Friends Group meeting the last Thursday of each month at 5:30pm. We hope to celebrate another year with you in the future! THANKS!!!

Meet our new Children's Services Coordinator, Chelsea Gifford! PCL: What are you reading today? CG: I just finished the young adult book "Looking for Alaska" by John Green. PCL: Besides being a children's librarian, what do you like to do for fun? CG: Obviously, I really love to read, but outside of that, I like spending time with friends and family and playing with my dog. I also love to travel. PCL: What has been your favorite part of this week? CG: Getting to know the people that I work with, being surrounded by children's literature, and planning programs for the kiddos!

Wise words: If this nation is to be wise as well as strong, if we are to achieve our destiny, then we need more new ideas for more wise men reading more good books in more public libraries. These libraries should be open to all¡ªexcept the censor. We must know all the facts and hear all the alternatives and listen to all the criticisms. Let us welcome controversial books and controversial authors. For the Bill of Rights is the guardian of our security as well as our Library. ¡ªJohn F. Kennedy, October 29, 1960

BANNED BOOK: The Dairy of a Young Girl This one is a little sad. First, to be clear that the banned version of Anne Frank's writings is not the version depicted here, but the definitive edition. Why you ask? Because it adds about 30% more content that she left out of the original publication. What was added that was so offensive that it was challenged? There are passages she described her anatomy and changes to her body, which some deem as "pornographic". Frank had no resources to answer her questions about her physical changes and relied on her observations to answer them as best she could. One could argue that teenagers can relate with the confusing physical changes of puberty on top of stress from situations they do not fully control. Thus, it might behoove teenagers to read Frank's diary as it could possibly start a dialogue about their own anatomical questions. That is the beauty of literature. You can use someone's perspective to question and grow. Reason: "Pornographic" Passages

BANNED BOOK: The Kite Runner by Khaled Hosseini This book about an Afghan boy growing up in Kabul has been challenged for numerous reasons.The most recent was in May of this year due to profanity, adult themes and rape of a child. While shocking, the rape is used as a driving force for the book's main themes of guilt and redemption. Amir, the protagonist, witnesses the act but doesn't prevent it. This is in contrast to the victim protecting Amir before this event. It really is worth the read. Reasons: Offensive language, unsuited to age group, violence

Some of these we all have read at least one of these books at one point or another. It's important to remember that we have the right and freedom to choose to read these thought provoking books. It's ?#?BannedBooksWeek?! Check out our interactive infographic with details on when and why these books got banned: https://www.aclu.org/infograp¡­/infographic-banned-books-week

Reasons: drugs/alcohol/smoking, offensive language, sexually explicit, and unsuited for age group

How many librarians does it take to catch a crow? We found out this afternoon when this guy was trapped with an injured wing in our courtyard. Good practice for some of our bird-themed Orem Reads events coming up in October such as a visit from Hawkwatch and a trip to Bear River Migratory Bird Refuge. ?#?librarywildlife? ?#?justanotherdayatthelibrary? ?#?catchingcrows? ?#?donttrythisathomekids?

Success! Though we very much wanted to tame him and keep him in the library by the Edgar Allan Poe section, we put our crow friend into a cardboard box with a blanket and air holes and called Wildlife Resources. ?#?catchingcrows? ?#?happyending? ?#?libraryadventures?

Thanks to City of Orem Government's shoutout on their whiteboard to our Orem Reads Kickoff TONIGHT at 7 pm with Terry Tempest Williams, one of the nation's foremost environmental writers and author of this year's Orem Reads selection, Refuge: An Unnatural History of Family and Place. Williams will read from and discuss Refuge and its deeply personal history, as well as the importance of home, nature, and place in the human experience. Free copies of Refuge will be distributed at the event and a signing with the author will follow the reading. Hope to see you there! ?#?OremReads? ?#?refuge? ?#?comeonecomeall?

READING BUDDIES NEEDED: The Jackson Library is in search of some middle-school students, high-school students and adults for the Reading Buddies program. You would be paired up with a 2nd or 3rd grade student and would meet once per week for 1/2 hour reading together. The student is working on their reading skills as well as reaching their AR goals. We are in need of weekly readers as well as substitute readers! If you are interested in becoming part of this fun successful program, stop in at the library for more info and to register. Feel free to call Carrie for more info as well 847-4748.

September is "Library Card Signup Month"! Register for a library card during the month of September and get a library card holder. Replace a library card FREE of charge! Watch for special events during September.

September is a library extravaganza! September 18th is the 2nd annual Read an eBook Day and we want you to participate!!! Just come down to the library anytime before September 18th and sign a Pledge sheet, pick up a reminder and get ready to read your eBook! Then on the day, sit back, relax and read your ebook smile emoticon As an added bonus we're doing a contest on Twitter to celebrate. All you have to do is send out a tweet about Read an eBook Day tagging the library (@JacksonCoReads) and using the hashtag, ?#?ebooklove?!

Everyone is invited to take part in the Pumpkin Decorating Contest at the Jackson, Lakefield or Heron Lake Libraries. You can enter a pumpkin into the contest or stop in your local library to vote for your favorite(s). All pumpkin entered into the contest must be decorated not carved and submitted on or before Oct. 16. Prizes will be awarded in 5 age categories from Kindergarten to adult! The money collected will be used by the Teen Advisory Group at each of the libraries. Stop in and check it out!!

Health Habits for a Healthier You 9/22, Emily Fowler Central Library at 4 p.m. Learn about research in the areas of diet and nutrition, exercise, cognitive activity and social engagement, and use hands-on tools to help you incorporate these recommendations into a plan for healthy aging. iPad for Seniors: The Basics 9/14, North Branch at 1 p.m. Learn how to connect your iPad to the public Wi-Fi, explore the external features, discuss battery issues, and practice navigation skills like swiping, opening/closing apps, and using the Home button. This class is designed to provide confidence for senior citizens who have minimal experience using an iPad. Please bring your own iPad. Registration required. Register at 940-349-8752 or www.dentonlibrary.com

Maker Teen: Recycled Paper Jewelry 9/15, South Branch from 4:30-5:30 p.m. Learn how to create bracelets and earrings from recycled paper and comic books. All supplies provided. For ages 11-18. Registration required at 940-349-8752 or www.dentonlibrary.com.

Bilingual StoryTime! 9/12 (Saturday), 11 a.m. at Emily Fowler Central Library Hola! Join us for a bilingual StoryTime featuring stories, songs, and puppets. This will be a great learning opportunity for English and Spanish speakers alike.

FREE MATH TUTORING! We are pleased to invite your child to enroll in FREE math tutoring for grades K through 12. Dr. Gil Lee, professor at UT Dallas, will lead the program with help from community and UNT volunteers. Classes will be held every Saturday from 10 AM to 12:00 PM beginning September 5th at the Emily Fowler Library located at 502 Oakland Street, Denton. All materials needed will be provided. However, if students have math homework to complete, they may bring it with them. If you would like your child to participate in this program, please pick up a form at any of the branch of the Denton Public Library and return it to the library with your child¡¯s report card. You can also e-mail us at library@cityofdenton.com to have the form sent to you. We will take up to 30 students. It is first come, first serve.

Working with Word (3 part class) Tuesday 08/18, 08/25, 09/01 at North Branch (The Forge) from 6:30-8:30 pm This basic Microsoft Word class is for newer computer users; instruction moves at a slower pace than in other library Word classes. Provides basic instruction in using Word 2007. Must know how to use keyboard, mouse, save and retrieve files in Windows. Participants must be able to attend all classes in the series. Registration required at 940-349-8752 or www.dentonlibrary.com.

Do you know someone that needs help learning to use a computer but is more comfortable communicating in Spanish. This class might be perfect for them. Critterman: Squirm Factor! 07/17, 3 p.m. at Emily Fowler Central Library Meet and learn about animals from around the world that can make you squirm! See everything from a tarantula to a hissing cockroach to a Burmese python. Tickets will be available one hour before show time on a first come, first served basis. Ages 5 and older.

25 Years in the Making: The Upshaws of County Line: An American Family 7/11, Emily Fowler Central Library at 3 p.m. Author and photographer, Richard Orton will talk about his book The Upshaws of County Line: An American Family and the 25 year experience documenting the Upshaw family and the freedom colony County Line, located in northwest Nacogdoches County. Copies of the book will be available for purchase. No registration required.

Our Family Night for kindergarten through 3rd grade will be held at 6:30 p.m. on Monday, October 12. We will be reading the book "Pumpkin Town," making a jack-o-lantern craft, playing a pumpkin rolling game, and enjoying refreshments. Each child will receive a free book. Since space is limited, reservations are required and can be made by calling 471-4140.

They're back!! The first Family Night of the year is scheduled for 6:30 p.m. on Monday, October 5 for preschoolers. Parents as Teachers will present a celebration of fall, with reading, flannel board stories, crafts and refreshments. Space is limited, so call us at 471-4140 to reserve a spot for you and your child soon!
The library will be closed tomorrow (Monday, Sept. 7) due to Labor Day.

The Summer Reading Program for our young adults (entering grades 6 and up) wraps up with an end-of-summer party. Snacks, fun trivia games, and lots of prizes are all ready to go. No reservations required, just come ready for fun!

Join us for preschool storytime at 10 a.m. Wednesday for "Heroes Save the World!" We will be reading "The Grand Old Tree" and "The Busy Tree." Don't forget crafts, snacks and singing too! No reservations required, just join us ready for fun!

Children entering third through fifth grades...join us at 1:30 pm Tuesday as we finish with the adventures of Melvin Beederman, Superhero. In addition to stories, we will play games, enjoy snacks, and make a super hero paddle ball craft. No reservations needed, just show up ready for fun!

Summer reading today for our youngest and oldest kiddos. Preschool storytime at 10 a.m. with "Farm Flu" and "Froggy Goes to the Doctor." Summer reading for young adults begins at 1:30 p.m. with superheroes and creating your own comic. No reservations required, just show up ready for fun!

Summer reading for grades 3-5 continues tomorrow afternoon at 1:30 p.m. at the library. We will continue with "Melvin Beederman Superhero," followed by games, snacks and craft. No reservations required!

Join us tomorrow evening at 6:30 p.m. as master storyteller Loretta Washington presents "My Corner of the Porch: Stories from My Childhood in the Missouri Bootheel." Ms. Washington's program is entertaining for all ages, and recommended for first grade through adults. This program was made possible by a Spotlight on Literacy grant from the Missouri State Library and the Institute of Museum and Library Services.

Summer reading for kids entering kindergarten through second grade continues at 1:30 p.m. on Monday. We will be looking at Environmental Heroes with the story "The Camping Trip That Changed America." Our special guest will be an environmentalist with the Army Corps of Engineers. On top of that, there will be games, crafts and snacks too! No reservations required, just show up ready for fun!

Young adults (entering grade 6 and up) are invited to the library Wednesday at 1:30 p.m. for games and crafts around the theme "villains and anti-heroes." What exactly IS an anti-hero? You'll learn all about it tomorrow. Plus, where else do you get to make your own wanted poster? No reservations required; just show up for the fun.

"Every Hero Has a Story" at preschool story time tomorrow at 10 a.m. We will be learning about The Hero Inside Me as we read "I'm Growing" by Aliki and "I Like Myself" by popular children's author Karen Beaumont. No reservation required; just join us for the fun!

Children entering kindergarten through second grade are invited to the library at 1:30 p.m. this afternoon for "Community Heroes." We will be reading the book "Officer Buckle and Gloria" and "No Dragons for Tea Firetruck." Please keep our community heroes in mind this morning!
libraries are where our past lives, our present grows, and our future is birthed.

We had a lot of fun in the young adult Summer Reading program last week; how often do you get to joust at the library?? Join us for more fun at 1:30 p.m. on Wednesday for historical heroes. Activities include a scavenger hunt, snacks and other surprises. No reservations required!

Preschool storytime, 10 a.m. Wednesday -- Community Heroes! We will be reading "Clothesline Clues to Jobs People Do" and "Whose Hat Is This?" Come join us for stories, crafts, and snacks, no reservations required!

Attention kids going into third through fifth grades -- join us at 1:30 p.m. on Tuesday for the continuing adventures of "Melvin Beederman Superhero!" Don't worry if you missed last week; Ms. Ann will recap what happened last week. After we get caught up with Melvin, we will be making a superhero initial craft, enjoying games, and eating snacks. No reservations required!

Patrons come into the Reference Room with all sorts of requests. Some of the questions we answered today include: How can I find a GED program in Paterson? How can I learn to use Microsoft Publisher? Can you help me with this job application? Here is Mr. Noel assisting a patron, one of the nearly 145 that came into the department so far today! ?#?snapshotnj?

Sean came to the library today to research fire departments in Paterson and New Jersey. Here he is with the Local History books Mr. Bruce found for him. Before he left, he exclaimed, "This is a great library!" We're so happy to help!
Today is Snapshot Day in libraries all across New Jersey. We want to capture a day in the life of your library. So far today, over 75 people have already visited PFPL! ?#?snapshotnj?
Next week, we're continuing a new film series - "The Criminal 5"! Five films that are so good - it's felonious! The next film is "Point Blank" - Tuesday, October 6th at 5:30pm. Be there!

Basics of Going Solar - tonight form 7-8:30pm. Meeting Room B Oregon is sunny enough for solar! This FREE workshop will teach you why Solar Energy is a smart choice for Oregon homeowners.

Basics of Going Solar October 13, 7:00 PM - 8:30 PM @ Beaverton City Library This free workshop will be held at the Beaverton City Library on Tuesday, October 13, 2015 from 7:00 to 8:30 p.m. Attendees will walk away with an understanding of why solar is a smart choice for Oregon homeowners. Topics that will be covered include: ? How solar works in Oregon¡¯s climate ? Available solar technologies and how they fit into your overall energy use ? How financial incentives and tax credits can cover up to 80% of the cost ? Ownership, Leasing, power purchase and financing options Workshop participants will come away with basic knowledge about solar energy systems and will be prepared to do more focused research on their own, use Mapdwell, or start working with a solar contractor. Free and open to the public. No registration required
